thread.title: Marcus Cannon, Stevan Ridley, Dion Lewis | Jets-New England Patriots injury report
thread.title_full: Marcus Cannon, Stevan Ridley, Dion Lewis | Jets-New England Patriots injury report | NJ.com

author: Dom Cosentino | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Marcus Cannon, Stevan Ridley, Dion Lewis | Jets-New England Patriots injury report
text:
Marcus Cannon, the Patriots' backup left tackle, was officially declared out with a toe injury for Sunday's game against the visiting Jets , according to the official injury report released Friday afternoon.
The Patriots will also be without linebacker Rufus Johnson (illness) and defensive end Jabaal Sheard (ankle). The only player out for the Jets will be running back Bilal Powell (ankle), which leads to the question of whether the Jets will activate running back Stevan Ridley from the PUP list.
Jets running back Stevan Ridley's name did not appear on Friday's injury report because the Jets have still not activated him from the PUP list (knee). Head coach Todd Bowles said the coaching staff would evaluate whether to do so Friday evening. For Ridley to be eligible to play Sunday, he must be activated by 4 p.m. Saturday.
Cannon was hurt last week at the Colts, the first game he played in place of Nate Solder, who's out for the season with a torn biceps.
The Pats are already without starting center Bryan Stork, who's on short-term IR. Last week, after Cannon was injured, they moved right tackle Sebastian Vollmer to the left side and had Cameron Fleming play on the right side. Fleming had only been activated from the practice squad a day earlier.
The Jets' defense has been fantastic this season, their defensive front in particular. A patchwork Patriots line is obviously advantageous for the Jets, but quarterback Tom Brady, per Pro Football Focus, has been taking just 2.19 seconds to get rid of the ball this seasonâ€”fastest in the league.
Right guard Willie Colon is questionable for the Jets with a knee injury, but Bowles said Colon hadn't had any setbacks.
Wide receiver Chris Owusu, who is probable, told NJ Advance Media on Thursday he felt good to go.
For the latest on Jets slot corner Buster Skrine (concussion), click here .
